description: From Old French molture (modern French mouture), from Medieval Latin molitura, from the past participle stem of molere ‘grind’. Compare mill.

entries.meaning: A grinding of grain, or the grain that is ground.
(Scotland, historical) A toll paid to a miller, mill-owner etc., generally in kind, for grinding corn or pulverizing ore.

verbs.description: multure (third-person singular simple present multures, present participle multuring, simple past and past participle multured)

entries.meaning: (Scotland, historical, transitive) To charge a multure on.
